Substitution of water samples from overexploited groundwater tables (85 million m3 annually) with aboveground water sources.
Artificial replenishment of groundwater tables by up to 180 million m3/year.
Desalinization of seawater to reach a capacity of 500 million m3 per year by 2030
Substitution of water withdrawal (85 Million m3/year) from overexploited aquifers by withdrawals from surface water by 2020|Artificial refill of aquifers with a potential of 180 Million m3 by 2030

Sustainable Land Management practice will be implemented in 15% of Eritrean total land covered
Development and establishment of new enclosure areas over 750,000 ha

Sustainable Land Management practiced will be implemented in 15% of Eritrean the total
land covered;

Switching from current irrigation systems to localized irrigation systems over an area of 550,000 hectares by 2020
Irrigate 15,000 hectares by desalinating water from the Chtouka Ait Baha plain by 2020
Develope the public-private partnerships to delegate irrigation for the coastal Azemmour-Bir Jdid area, over 3,200 hectares by 2020.
Hydro-agricultural infrastructure around dams over 160,000 hectares by 2020
Extension of irrigation to new agricultural areas by over 260,000 hectares by 2030
Equip and modernize irrigation systems over 290,000 hectares
The replenishment of 200,000 hectares of forests by 2020

To have an adaptive management strategy in 20% of the coastal line of the Uruguay River, the River Plate and the Atlantic Ocean by 2025, prioritizing the most vulnerable stretches.
To have, by 2020, a system for monitoring and assessing adaptation actions in the six coastal departments in coordination with institutions dealing with coastal areas.

To have diversified, by 2025, the power grid sources, thus reducing the vulnerabilities resulting from the dependence of hydropower generation on climate conditions, with at least 1,700 installed MW from at least three non-traditional sources, and with the option of power accumulation plants
To have formulated, adopted and implemented by 2025 three integrated basin management plans that consider climate change and variability.

To have relocated, by 2025, between 3500 and 6000 of the households in flood or contaminated zones identified through the National Relocation Plan and other national and departmental instruments, enabling access to basic services to relocated population and assigning new uses to give a different significance to flood zones.
To have formulated by 2025 a diagnosis of the response capacity and the infrastructure of health care services and centers to extreme weather events in at least four departments.

To have, by 2020, six regional risk-management plans (covering the entire country), those taking into account climate change and variability, with focus in urban and rural population depending on specific vulnerability characteristics.
Departmental risk-management instruments consider at least 25% of municipal areas, and include the participation and perspective of the third level of government by 2025.
At least seven departments will have regional, departmental or municipal local climate change and variability adaptation plans by 2025.
The management plans of at least six protected areas will include climate change and variability considerations by 2025.
To restore 500,000 additional hectares until 2017 and increase total by 100,000 hectares per year until 2025
Transfer 800 million m3 of water per year from north to south by 2030
Wastewater treatment plant established to treat 3 million m3 of water/year
Wastewater treatment plant established to treat 3 million m3 of water/year;
